intro: Fimbristylis sieboldii subsp. anpinensis, commonly known as the Anpin sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to East Asia. It typically grows in wet or marshy habitats, showcasing its adaptation to moist environments. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered spikelets that are characteristic of the Cyperaceae family. It is often found in wetlands, rice fields, and other aquatic or semi-aquatic areas. Due to its ecological importance, it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
